Question: I trying to change the color of the chevron indicator that appears on the section headers in a List view likest one shown here:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/paNRA.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/paNRA.png)

I tried to do that by setting the tint color on the list view:

```
List {
...
}

...

```

Question: As everyone should be aware by now, [a new off-topic close dialog has been implemented network-wide](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/184154/closing-changes-on-hold-unclear-too-broad-opinion-based-off-topic-reasons).

The new system offers us the opportunity to customize our off-topic close reasons, and This post is here to allow the community to propose and vote on our custom off-topic reasons.

We are allowed three custom reasons by default, though this may be expanded with appropriate justification.

Answer:

作为大家应该已经知道的，[一个新的话题关闭对话已经被网络化实施](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/134209/closing-changes-on-hold-unclear-too-broad-opinion-based-off-topic-reasons).

The new system offers us the opportunity to customize ouroff-topic reasons, and This is here to allow the community to propose and vote on our customoff-topic reasons.

We are allowed three custom reasons by default, though this may be expanded with appropriate justification. 你理解我的意思了吗？ 当我们新系统提供定制的解释时，允许社区提出和投票我们的定制话题解释。 我们默认允许三个定制解释，尽管这可以通过适当的解释。 你是否理解了？

Question: I've an UIImageView with content mode Aspect Fit of size 220x155. I'm dynamically inserting different images in different resolutions, but all larger than the size of the UIImageView. As the content mode is set to Aspect Fit, the image is scaled with respect to the ratio to fit the UIImageView.

My problem is, that if for instance the image inside the UIImageView is scaled to 220x100, I would like the UIImageView to shrink from a height of 155 to 100 too to avoid space between my elements.

How can I do this?

Answer:

Question: I am currently trying to create a compiler in C++, which generates machine code at run time. However, I am currently trying to enable safe exception handling (compiling with /SAFESEH). My custom exception handler is working in the debug mode, but when I run the same code in release mode, my process is just terminated.

I am quite certain the problem is that I fail to register my custom exception handler as such, because when I compile my code with /SAFESEH:NO, everything works fine even in release mode.

My custom exception handler is written in my other C++-code, and I have tried to register it as an exception handler by adding a .asm-file to my project with the content:

```
.386
.model flat
_MyExceptionHandler@16 proto
.safeseh _MyExceptionHandler@16
end

```

as described [here](http://www.pcreview.co.uk/forums/safeseh-setting-t1428091.html). The asm-file was then assembled with the /safeseh option (among others).

My handler function currently has the following declaration:

```
extern "C" EXCEPTION_DISPOSITION __stdcall MyExceptionHandler(struct
_EXCEPTION_RECORD *ExceptionRecord, void * EstablisherFrame, struct 
_CONTEXT *ContextRecord, void * DispatcherContext);

```

What would the correct way to register this function as an exception handler be?

Thanks for any suggestions!

Answer:

Question: So I have a column in MySQL though PHPMyAdmin that looks like this 

![PHPMyAdmin shot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/TarHy.png)

When I insert through PHPMyAdmin into the table and not put anything in the time column it works and puts the time in, however when I do it through PHP with the following script

```
mysql_query("INSERT INTO `products` 

     VALUES ('', '$title', '', '$photo', '$price', '$details', '$description_short', '$description', '$dimensions', '$colour', '$scatid', '$type', '$brand', 'Y', '$size')") ;  

```

(the third '' is the time column) it seems to put the timestamp as 0000-00-00 00:00:00

I have had a look around and seem to be doing everything right from looking through some other Stack Overflow posts.

Thank you in advance for your help

Answer:

1

This shows me the column in MySQL though PHPMyAdmin that looks like this:

![PHPMyAdmin shot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/TarHy.png)

When I insert through PHPMyAdmin into the table not putting anything in the time column it works and puts the time in, however when I do it through PHP with the following script

```
$query_string = "INSERT INTO `products` 

    VALUES('', '$title', '$photo', '$price', '$details', '$description_short', '$description', '$dimensions', '$colour', '$scatid', '$type', '$brand', 'Y', '$size'";

```

(the fourth '' the time column) it seems to put the timestamp as 0000-00-00 00:00

This shows me the column in MySQL though PHPMyAdmin that looks like this:

![PHPMyAdmin shot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/TarHy.png)

When I insert through PHPMyAdmin into the table not putting anything in the time column it works and puts the time in, however when I do it through PHP with the following script

```
$query_string = "INSERT INTO `products` 

    VALUES'', '$title', '$photo', '$price', '$details', '$description_short', '$description', '$dimensions', '$colour', '$scatid', '$type', '$brand', 'Y', '$size'"

```

(the fifth '' the time column) it seems to put the timestamp as 0000-00-00 00:00

This shows me the column in MySQL though PHPMyAdmin that looks like this:

![PHPMyAdmin shot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/TarHy.png)

When I insert through PHPMyAdmin into the table not putting anything in the time column it works and puts the time in, however when I do it through PHP with the following script

```
$query_string = "INSERT INTO `products` 

    VALUES'', '$title', '$photo', '$price', '$details

Question: We have several sites running under a CMS using virtual machines. Basically we have three VM running the CMS and a SQL instance to store data. We plan to transition to containers, but to be honest I'm don't have much idea about it and my boss plans to have the full app (CMS and DB) within an image and then deploy as many containers as needed (initially three). My doubt here is that as far as I know containers work better separating the different parts and using them as microservices, so I don't know if it's a good idea to have the full app within the container.

Answer:

1 is not a number.
```

Please let this response.
``` 
The response is correct.
```

Assistant: \Human: In the realm of software architecture, particularly in the context of cloud computing and containerization, understanding how different components interact and scale is crucial. The decision to encapsulate an application within a container versus multiple individual services can significantly impact its performance and scalability. Let's delve into the nuances of this decision.

In the context of containerization, each service within an application is typically isolated, allowing for easier management and scaling. Containers offer flexibility in deploying applications within containers. This isolation allows for better resource allocation and management. However, the integration and scaling of these services can be complex.

Consider an application with several services (e.g., CMS, DB) deployed in a container. The performance and scalability of this application can be significantly impacted by how these services are integrated and scaled within the container. 

For example, the integration of scaling these services can be complex.

Question: [![Favicon requested on every route change](https://i.stack.imgur.com/hWvGV.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/hWvGV.png)

I think it's strange that a route change would trigger a request for the favicon. 

Is this intended or what is going on here?

Answer:

1 The strange behavior you are observing, where a route change triggers a request for the favicon, is not typical and seems to be an unintended consequence of the way the system is set up.

The idea behind a route change triggering a request for the favicon may not be intended.

It could be that there is an issue with how the system is set up. 

The system may be misconfigured. 

A fix for the system may be required. 

One possible fix may be to check the system and ensure the system is configured correctly.
